questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a forensic examination in a case involving a late-term abortion. To assist in determining the gestational age of the fetus at the time of the abortion, the medical officer is reviewing the mother's medical records for documented physical examination findings. External ballottement is a technique used to assess fetal development. After how many weeks of gestation can external ballottement typically be performed in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

External ballottement, a technique where the fetus can be felt to rebound against the examiner's fingers during a pelvic examination, is typically possible after about 20 weeks of gestation. This is when the fetus is large enough to be palpated through the abdominal wall.

 

Demonstration

 

  • Vaginal/internal ballottement: Two fingers are inserted into the anterior fornix and a sudden upward motion given. This causes the fetus to move up in the liquor amnii and after a moment, the fetus drops down on the fingers, like a ball bouncing back.
  • External ballottement: A sudden motion is given to the abdominal wall covering the uterus, in a few seconds the rebound of the fetus can be felt.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ballottement (toss up like a ball): This is positive during the 4th–5th month of pregnancy as the fetus is small in relation to the amount of amniotic fluid present. This is a useful clinical sign for assessing fetal development around the midpoint of the gestation period.

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 394

choices.text: Abnormality of the uterus

questions.text: During a medical conference, a discussion arises about the different causes of spontaneous abortion in the second trimester. What is the most common cause of spontaneous abortion in the second trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervical incompetence

 

Option B:

 

Cervical incompetence, characterized by the inability of the cervix to retain a pregnancy, is the most common cause of spontaneous abortions in the second trimester. This condition leads to premature dilation and effacement of the cervix, often resulting in mid-pregnancy loss.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chromosomal defect: More common in the first trimester.

 

Option C. Abnormality of the uterus: Less common than cervical incompetence for second-trimester losses.

 

Option D. Infections: While a potential cause, they are not as common as cervical incompetence in the second trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical incompetence is the primary cause of second-trimester abortion, underscoring the significance of cervical integrity in maintaining pregnancy.

Cervico-uterine (Anatomic) factors usually cause second trimester abortions.

 

  • Cervical incompetence.
  • Congenital malformation of uterus, e.g. hypoplasia, bicornuate/septate uterus or duplication of upper part of uterus.
  • Uterine fibroid

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 400

choices.text: Amniotic fluid embolism

questions.text: In a pathology laboratory, a medical officer is analyzing tissue samples from a deceased pregnant woman who suddenly collapsed and died. The medical history and symptoms prior to death suggest a rare but serious complication. The medical officer decides to use Lendrum's stain in the histopathological examination of the lung tissue. For which type of embolism is Lendrum's stain specifically used?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amniotic fluid embolism

 

Option C:

 

Lendrum’s stain (Phloxine-Tartrazine): This stain is useful to detect amniotic fluid embolism deaths, since keratin of amniotic squames is stained red, nuclei blue and cytoplasm yellow.

 

The ‘WHO’ method: It is helpful to demonstrate keratin and mucin-like substances in amniotic fluid embolism.

 

Some important Pointers related to Amniotic Fluid Embolism

 

  • Most of the cases occur during: 1st and 2nd trimester abortion;  Active labor; Amniocentesis; Abdominal trauma
  • Amniotic fluid embolism is a rare, unforeseeable and dreadful complication. This occurs when massive amount of amniotic fluid enters the maternal venous system.
  • There may be tonic-clonic seizures, breathlessness and loss of consciousness. In half the cases, death occurs in the first hour.
  • It causes DIC and fibrin deposition in many organs.
  • Diagnosis is established by demonstration of mucin, lanugo hair, vernix caseosa, fat globules, meconium and fetal squamous cells in cut sections of the lung.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Air embolism: Not identifiable with Lendrum's stain.

 

Option B. Fat embolism: Detected through different staining techniques.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: The nature of the embolus (e.g., thrombus, fat, air) dictates the staining technique, not the location.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lendrum's stain is used in forensic pathology for the identification of amniotic fluid embolism, a critical diagnostic tool in cases of maternal death where this condition is suspected.

 

Cause of Death in Criminal Abortion

 

  • Immediate: Air embolism, fat embolism, amniotic fluid embolism, hemorrhage, vagal inhibition.
  • Delayed (with 2 to 3 days): Septicemia, generalized peritonitis, tetanus, local infection & toxemia.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 410

choices.text: Injuries sustained are non-accidental
Undue delay in seeking medical advice
The history is consistent with the injuries
Injuries are of different duration

questions.text: In a lecture on child abuse, the professor discusses Caffey's Syndrome, a condition often associated with non-accidental injuries in children. The students are asked to identify which feature is not true regarding Caffey's Syndrome. Which of the following statements about Caffey's Syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The history is consistent with the injuries.

 

Option C:

 

In cases of Caffey's Syndrome, which is often associated with child abuse, the history provided by caregivers often does not correlate with the injuries observed, making option C incorrect.

 

Battered Baby Syndrome: It is also known as child abuse syndrome, Caffey’s syndrome or non-accidental injury of childhood. The classical features are:

 

  1. Discrepancy between the nature of injuries and the explanation offered by the parents.
  2. Delay between injury and medical attention cannot be explained by caregiver.
  3. Injuries of different age groups
  4. Victims are usually male of less than 3 years old and belong to low social class and education.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Injuries sustained are non-accidental: True, as Caffey's Syndrome is often linked to child abuse.

 

Option B. Undue delay in seeking medical advice: True, and this delay in seeking treatment is a common feature in child abuse cases.

 

Option D. Injuries are of different duration: True, indicating repeated abuse over time, with injuries in various stages of healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of nonaccidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian. In addition to physical injury, there may be non-accidental deprivation of nutrition, care and affection. The key identifier is the inconsistency between the history provided and the injuries observed, which is a hallmark of non-accidental injury in child abuse cases.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 445

questions.text: A group of medical students are discussing the medicolegal aspects associated with precipitate labor. One topic of particular interest is the risk of umbilical cord rupture. As part of their discussion, they focus on identifying the most common site of umbilical cord tear during such rapid deliveries. Umbilical cord in precipitate labor usually torn at?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fetal end

 

Option B:

 

In cases of precipitate labor, the umbilical cord is most commonly torn at the fetal end. This is typically due to the rapid expulsion of the fetus, causing a sudden and intense stretch on the cord.

 

Medicolegal aspect

 

  • Accidental drowning may occur in precipitate labor, when the baby may fall into a bathtub or lavatory pan and die
  • Death of baby is mostly due to head injury, suffocation or drowning, or occasionally due to bleeding from torn end of attached umbilical cord, may be taken as a case of deliberate infanticide.
  • The mother may claim infanticide (negligence on part of the doctor), but death of the newborn is due to precipitate labor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Placental end: Tearing at the placental end is less common because this end is typically more securely attached and less susceptible to the rapid forces experienced in precipitate labor.

 

Option C. Mid part: The mid part of the umbilical cord is structurally stronger and less likely to tear under the stress of a rapid delivery compared to the fetal end.

Option D. Lower third part: This is not a common site of rupture during precipitate labor. The stress on the umbilical cord during rapid delivery is more likely to affect the fetal end, where the cord is attached to the fetus and thus more vulnerable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In precipitate labor all three stages of labor merge into one (mostly in multipara). Cord is torn most commonly at the fetal end than the placental end, but is not torn in its middle part or the placenta is expelled with the child.

 

Differentiation between Head injury due to precipitate labor and blunt force –

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 443

If a lady doctor is not available in the hospital, the victim can be examined by a male doctor in the presence of a lady attendant

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting a workshop on the POCSO Act for medical professionals who often deal with cases of child sexual abuse. The expert discusses various provisions of the act and tests the participants' knowledge by asking them to identify an incorrect statement regarding the POCSO Act.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The victim can give consent for sex if she is above 12 years of age

 

Option C:

 

The POCSO Act defines a child as any person below the age of 18 years and provides protection to all children (both males and females) under the age of 18 years from sexual abuse. The consent for sexual activity is invalid if child is below 18 years of age.

 

Some Important Pointers

 

  • For speedy trial, the evidence of the child has to be recorded within a period of 30 days. The Special Court has to complete the trial within 1 year.

  • The burden of proof is shifted on the accused, keeping in view the vulnerability and innocence of children.

  • To prevent misuse of the law, punishment is given for false complaints or false information with malicious intent.

  • The media is barred from disclosing the identity of the child without the permission of the Special Court. The punishment for breaching this provision is imprisonment from 6 months to 1 year.

  • childs statement can be recorded even at the childs residence or a place of her choice and should be preferably done by a female police officer not below the rank of sub-inspector (if the victim is a female).

  • The childs medical examination can be conducted even prior to registration of an FIR, in a government hospital or local hospital within 24 h of receiving information about the offence. This is done with the consent of the child or parent or a competent person whom the child trusts and in their presence.

  • An offence is treated as aggravated when committed by a person in a position of trust or authority of child, such as a member of security forces, police officer, public servant, etc.

  • There is provision for punishment even in abetment or an attempt to commit the offences defined in the Act. The punishment for the attempt to commit is up to half the punishment prescribed for the commission of the offence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This is correct; the POCSO Act protects all children under the age of 18.

 

Option B. This is a provision in the act to ensure the examination is conducted ethically.

 

Option D. Correct, the POCSO Act was indeed passed in 2012.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POCSO - A child as any person below the age of 18 years and provides protection to all children under the age of 18 years from the offences of sexual assault, sexual harassment , pornography, sexual abuse and exploitation.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 425

questions.text: In a criminal case involving child abuse, a forensic expert is asked to categorize a specific type of paraphilic disorder. The suspect in the case derives sexual gratification from physically abusing children. What is the medical term for this type of behavior?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dippoldism

 

Option C:

 

Dippoldism is the correct term for a paraphilic disorder where an individual derives sexual pleasure from physically abusing children, typically through beating.

 

Sexual perversions (sexual deviations) - are persistently indulged sexual acts or fantasies in which complete satisfaction is sought and obtained without sexual intercourse. Perversions are acts which are socially prohibited or unacceptable, or biologically undesirable.

 

Diagnosis - The person must have experience in the perversion for a period of six months or more, and the behaviour must cause significant distress or impairment in social, occupational or other significant areas of the individual's functioning.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sapphism: Refers to lesbianism, not related to child abuse.

 

Option B. Udinism: In this the sexual pleasure is often obtained by witnessing the act of urination by someone of the same or opposite sex.

 

Option D. Troilism: Refers to a sexual arrangement involving three people, not child abuse. It is an extreme degree of voyeurism. Pervert gets sexual gratification by inducing his wife to have sexual intercourse with another man and by observing the same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dippoldism - Sexual gratification from beating children. Supposedly named after Dippold, a German schoolmaster.

 

Undinism: Sexual pleasure is often obtained by witnessing the act of urination

 

Sapphism: Lesbianism

 

Troilism: Sexual arrangement involving three people.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 430-433

questions.text: During a legal conference on reproductive rights, a forensic expert is discussing the definition of abortion in the context of gestational age. The expert is clarifying the legal definition of when an abortion is considered to occur. Legally, abortion is defined as the expulsion of the product of conception at what point of gestation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) At any point of gestation

 

Explanation:

 

The medical and legal definition of abortion are different

Legal definition of abortion expulsion of products of conception from the uterus at any period before full term.

 

Medical definition of abortion: Expulsion of products of conception from the uterus before the fetus can survive outside the uterus (i.e. before the age of viability). 

 

Abortus: The non-viable product of abortion.

 

Abortifacient: Any agent that induces abortion.

 

New abortion law, India - In September 2021, the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (Amendment) Act of 2021 came into force, extending the upper gestational limit for abortion from 20 to 24 weeks.

 

Criminal abortion: It is the termination of a pregnancy in violation of the legal regulations in force. Legal aspects - Dealt under Section 312316 IPC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Legally, abortion is defined as the expulsion of the product of conception at any point during gestation. This broad definition encompasses various scenarios and stages of pregnancy.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 400-401

Unlawful destruction of a child under the age of 1 year.
It includes the death of a fetus during the process of labor
In India, it is punishable under a special Act

questions.text: A legal case involves the death of an infant less than a year old, and the charge is infanticide. Understanding the legal definition of infanticide is crucial for the prosecution. Which statement correctly defines infanticide under the Indian law?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Unlawful destruction of a child under the age of 1 year.

 

Option B:

 

In Indian law, infanticide refers to the unlawful killing of a child under the age of one year, distinguished from other forms of homicide.

 

Other definitions:

 

  • Feticide is the killing of fetus at any time prior to birth.

  • Filicide (Latin filius: son) is deliberate act of killing of a child by the parents.

  • A stillborn child is one, which is born after twenty-eighth week of pregnancy, and which did not breathe or show any other signs of life, at any time after being completely born.

  • DEADBIRTH: A dead born child is one which has died in utero, and shows one of the following signs after it is completely born. (1) Rigor mortis at delivery. (2) Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis, occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about three or four days surrounded with liquor amnii but the exclusion of air. If air enters the liquor amnii after death of the foetus, putrefaction occurs instead of maceration.

 

Legal Aspects:

 

  • In India, there is no such special Act, and as such there is no distinction between the murder of newborn infant and that of any other individual.

  • Infanticide does not include the death of fetus during labor, when it is destroyed by craniotomy or decapitation

  • Death of the newborn due to precipitate labor may be taken as a case of deliberate infanticide

  • The charge of infanticide cannot be supplemented, if the infant can be proved under the age of seven months of intrauterine life.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The destruction of a child within 28 days of birth falls under Neonaticide is the deliberate killing of a child within 4 weeks of its birth.

 

Option C. The death of a fetus during labor is classified as stillbirth/ stillborn.

 

Option D. Although punishable, infanticide does not fall under a special Act but is treated under the broader penal code.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Legal definition of infanticide in India, i.e. unlawful killing of a child under the age of one year.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 437

questions.text: In a forensic training session, the instructor emphasizes the correct sequence of cavity examination during a fetal autopsy. Knowing the proper procedure is crucial for accurate determination of cause and time of death. Which cavity should be opened first in a fetal autopsy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abdominal cavity

 

Option B:

 

In fetal autopsies, the abdominal cavity is typically opened first. This allows for the examination of the abdominal organs without interference from blood or fluid that might drain from the chest or cranial cavities. Abdomen should be opened before thorax to note the highest point of diaphragm. The position is affected by gases of decomposition.

 

  • At the level of 4th or 5th rib= If respiration has not taken place
  • At the level of 6th or 7th rib =If respiration has taken place.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The chest cavity is usually examined after the abdominal cavity. The whole chest cavity can be opened under water in order to demonstrate a pneumothorax.

 

Option C. The cranial cavity is often opened after the abdominal and chest cavities. In fetuses and infants, Beneke’s technique is used to open the skull.

 

Option D. The pelvic cavity is part of the overall abdominal examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the proper sequence of cavity examination in fetal autopsies for accurate forensic assessment. Before opening the thorax, the abdomen is opened first and position of diaphragm is noted by passing a finger.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 439

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting a workshop on various tests used to determine live birth in cases of infant death. These tests are essential to distinguish between infants who were born alive and those who were stillborn. Which of the following tests is not used to detect live birth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Winslow test

 

Option D:

 

Winslow’s test: No movement of reflection of light shown on mirror or surface of water in bowl kept on the chest. Now obsolete. The Winslow test is not specifically used to detect live birth.

 

Other Tests to detect stoppage of respiration (obsolete)

 

  • Feather test: No movement is seen, if a feather or fine cotton fibers are held before the nostrils.
  • Mirror test: No haziness is seen on the reflecting surface of the mirror held in front of mouth and nostrils.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fodere's test is used to demonstrate lung floatation, indicative of breathing and thus live birth. The lungs are ligated across their hila and separated. The average weight of both lungs before respiration varies from 30 to 40 g., and after respiration from 60 to 66 g. The increase in weight is due to the increased flow of blood.

 

Option B. Ploucquet's test is another lung floatation test used to determine if an infant had breathed. The ratio of the weight of the lungs and the whole body is reduced to half (1/35 of body weight) as compared to the said ratio before respiration (1/70 of body weight).

 

Option C. Wredin's test - Before birth, the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue but no air. With respiration, the sphincter at the pharyngeal end of eustachian tube relaxes and air replaces the gelatinous substances in few hours to five weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding different forensic tests used to detect live birth and distinguishing them from tests that serve other purposes.

 

  • Winslow test = test to determine stoppage of respiration
  • Fodere's test = weight of lungs before respiration -30 to 40 g after respiration-60 to 66 g
  • Plocquet's test = ratio of weight of lungs to weight of body; before respiration = 1:70 and after respiration = 1:35
  • Wredin's test = before respiration gelatinous tissue in middle ear & after respiration, air in middle ear

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 152, 439

questions.text: A forensic medicine student is studying the Spalding sign, a radiological indication of intrauterine fetal death. The student is asked about the presentation of the fetus where the Spalding sign is likely to develop earlier. Which fetal presentation is associated with an earlier development of the Spalding sign?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vertex presentation

 

Explanation:

 

Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and overriding of the bones of the cranial vault occur due to shrinkage of the cerebrum (brain) after death of the foetus. The sign will develop earlier with a vertex presentation than with a breech. It may be detected within 2 days of death of the foetus.

 

It is seen on X ray or ultrasound.

 

It is a sign of Maceration

 

 

Image shows overlapping of skull bones on ultrasound (Spalding sign)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of intrauterine fetal death (X ray/USG), the Spalding sign, characterized by overlapping skull bones, develops earlier in fetuses with a vertex presentation. This is because the pressure changes in the skull are more pronounced in this position after death.

 

This is the sign of maceration.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 437-438

questions.text: During a medicolegal investigation involving a childbirth-related death, a forensic expert is asked to classify the death of a child who expired during the process of delivery. What is the appropriate term for a child who dies during delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stillborn

 

Option A:

 

A child who dies during the process of delivery is termed as 'stillborn'. This term is specifically used when the fetus has died in the uterus or during delivery. The child was alive in utero, but dies during the process of birth. Stillbirths occur more frequently among illegitimate and immature male children in primipara.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dead born/ DEADBIRTH: A dead born child is one which has died in utero, and shows one of the following signs after it is completely born. (1) Rigor mortis at delivery. (2) Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis, occurs when the dead child remains in the uterus for about three or four days surrounded with liquor amnii but the exclusion of air. If air enters the liquor amnii after death of the foetus, putrefaction occurs instead of maceration.

 

Option C. Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) refers to the unexplained death of a baby, usually during sleep, after birth.

 

Option D. Maceration is a process that occurs if the fetus is retained in utero after its death, not applicable for deaths during delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A stillborn child is one, which is born after twenty-eighth week of pregnancy, and which did not breathe or show any other signs of life, at any time after being completely born.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 437

choices.text: Presence of large blebs in the skin
Reddish discoloration and skin slippage
Gas in the great vessels

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining a stillborn fetus to determine the time of death. The pathologist observes specific changes in the fetal body. Which of the following is considered the earliest sign of maceration in a stillborn fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reddish discoloration and skin slippage

 

Option B:

 

The earliest sign of maceration in a stillborn fetus is reddish discoloration and skin slippage. Maceration is a process that begins soon after fetal death if the fetus remains in the uterine environment.

 

Features:

 

  • The earliest sign of maceration is reddening of skin with peeling and slippage, which can be seen in 12 hours after the death of the child in utero.
  • Gas in great vessels (aorta in 12 hours) of foetus indicates foetal death (Robert's sign).
  • The body of a macerated foetus is soft, flaccid and flattens out when placed on a level surface. It has a sweetish, disagreeable odor.
  • Large blebs appear at 24 hours, which contain a red serous or serosanguineous fluid. The epidermis detaches easily and leaves moist and greasy areas. The tissues are reddish due to haemolysis and oedematous.
  • The abdomen is distended. The serous cavities may contain a turbid reddish fluid after 48 hours. The bones are flexible and readily detached from the soft parts. The joints become abnormally mobile.
  • All the viscera become soft and oedematous and lose their morphology, but lungs and uterus remain unchanged for a long time.
  • The umbilical cord is red, smooth, thickened and soft.
  • The skull bones are separated and the brain has a greyish-red pulpy appearance. Collapse of the vertebral column occurs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The presence of large blebs is a later sign of maceration.

 

Option C. Gas in the great vessels is an earliest radiological indicator of a dead born fetus (Robert sign)

 

Option D. Abdominal distension can occur post-mortem but is not specific to maceration nor the earliest sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  The earliest sign of maceration: skin slippage (12 hours)
  •  The earliest radiological sign of maceration: Robert sign (12 hours)
  •  Fluid filled bullae in the skin: 24 hours
  •  Sweetish disagreeable odor: 48 hours
  •  Spalding Sign (overlapping of fetal skull bones): 48 hours

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 437-438

choices.text: Presence of signs of maceration
Stomach contains milk

questions.text: A forensic resident is determining the necessity of performing a hydrostatic test in various scenarios involving fetal deaths. The hydrostatic test is used to assess whether the fetus had ever breathed. In which of the following situations is the hydrostatic test still required?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stillborn fetus

 

Option C:

 

The hydrostatic test is not required in cases where there are clear signs the fetus never breathed (like maceration or anencephaly). However, in a stillborn fetus where such signs are not present, the hydrostatic test can be valuable to determine if the fetus had breathed prior to death.

 

Hydrostatic test (floatation test or Raygat’s test)

 

  • Principle: It is based on the fact that specific gravity of lung before respiration is 1040–1050 and becomes 940-950 after respiration which is less than that of water. This makes the respired lung to float.
  • Procedure: Dissect out the fetal lungs. Put both the lungs (tied at their hilar region) into a trough of water and observe.
  • Inference
    • If they sink—unrespired lung.
    • If they float—remove them from water, cut into small pieces and then squeeze or compress firmly between sponges, and again put into water. If they sink—unrespired lung. If they float—respired lung.
    • Floatation observed for second time is because of residual air that remains in the lungs which cannot be squeezed out by pressing, if the fetus has breathed after birth.
  • The test is of limited value and it can at best be a suggestive pointer, but never a definitive test in itself.
  • Fallacies -
    • False positive is seen in accumulation of putrefying gases or artificial inflation (by intubation and forced air insufflation expanding the lungs with air after delivery).
    • False negative is seen in atelectasis (nonexpansion of lungs), obstruction by alveolar duct membrane, edema, feeble respiration, pneumonia and congenital syphilis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Maceration indicates prolonged intrauterine death, negating the need for a hydrostatic test.

 

Option B. The presence of milk in the stomach suggests postnatal ingestion, making the hydrostatic test irrelevant.

 

Option D. Anencephalic fetuses are typically incapable of independent respiration, making the test unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Learning the indications for performing the hydrostatic test in fetal autopsies to determine if the fetus had breathed. Hydrostatic test is not necessary if: Fetus shows congenital anomaly, like anencephaly; Fetus is macerated or mummified; Umbilical cord has separated and a scar has formed; Stomach contains milk; Bruises on lungs indicating efforts to artificially respirate the child; Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 439-440

questions.text: During autopsy of an infant, forensic expert is assessing whether the infant was born alive or stillborn. The presence of air in certain body cavities can be a significant indicator. What does the presence of air in the middle ear suggest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Live born

 

Option A:

 

The presence of air in the middle ear is indicative of a live birth, as it suggests that the infant took breaths after being born, allowing air to enter the middle ear. Before birth middle ear contains gelatinous connective tissue without air. But with respiration the sphincter at the pharyngeal end of eustachian tube relaxes and air replaces the gelatinous substance in few hours to five weeks. Middle ear must be opened under water by removing tegmen tympani. A bubble of air comes out if test is positive. It is also called Wreden-Wendt tympanic cavity or middle ear test. This is not at all reliable test.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dead born infants typically do not have air in their middle ears.

 

Option C. Stillborn infants, who have not breathed, would not have air in their middle ears.

 

Option D. SIDS involves infants who have lived for a period before dying suddenly, so air would be present but is not a distinguishing factor in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the significance of the presence of air in the middle ear as an indicator of live birth in infant autopsies (Wreden’s test)

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 441

choices.text: Air in stomach and small intestine
Meconium in the stomach and intestine
Air in the middle ear
Voluminous and crepitant lungs

questions.text: During a forensic investigation of an infant's death, the pathologist performs Breslau's second life test to determine whether the infant had lived after birth. This test is crucial for distinguishing between stillborn and live-born infants in medicolegal cases. Which finding is considered a positive result in Breslau's second life test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Air in stomach and small intestine

 

Option A:

 

A positive result in Breslau's second life test is indicated by the presence of air in both the stomach and small intestine. The stomach and intestine are removed after tying double ligatures at both ends. They float in water if respiration has taken place, otherwise they sink. This finding suggests that the infant had lived and breathed after birth, as air could only enter these areas through respiration.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Meconium in the stomach and intestine is not indicative of live birth.

 

Option C. Air in the middle ear suggests live birth but is not part of Breslau's second life test.

 

Option D. Voluminous and crepitant lungs indicate live birth but are not specific to Breslau's second life test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The application of Breslau's second life test in determining live birth in forensic examinations of infant deaths

 

  • Breslau's second life test (stomach bowel test): A live born child would respire and therefore, would also swallow some air into the stomach and bowel. The stomach and intestines are removed after tying double ligatures at each end. They float in water if respiration has taken place, otherwise they sink.
  • Please note that Breslau's First life test detects presence of air in lungs.
  • Both the tests are falsely positive in putrefaction (due to putrefied gases) or in cases of attempted artificial respiration.

questions.text: In a medicolegal autopsy of a newborn, a forensic expert is tasked with determining whether the infant had survived after birth and for how long. One critical aspect of the assessment is examining the status of the ductus arteriosus, as its closure timeline can provide valuable insights in cases of suspected neonatal demise under suspicious circumstances. How many days after live birth does the ductus arteriosus typically close?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10 days

 

Explanation:

 

After birth, significant physiological changes occur in a child's circulatory system as it adapts from fetal to neonatal circulation. One of the critical changes is the closure of the ductus arteriosus, a vital component of fetal circulation that allows blood to bypass the lungs. This closure typically occurs functionally within 10 days post-birth. The process begins with the contraction of the umbilical arteries, which usually starts within ten hours and completes by the third day.

 

Additionaly,  the timings of the closure of umbilical vein, ductus venosus,  foramen ovale, is essential for forensic experts to understand the newborn's adaptation to extrauterine life and can provide valuable insights in cases of neonatal demise under suspicious circumstances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Some important Changes in circulation to note -

 

  • Umbilical artery obliterates in 3 days (Forms Medial umbilical fold)
  • Umbilical vein (left) obliterate in 4 days (Forms Ligamentum Teres)
  • Change in umbilical cord—falls off in 5-6 days
  • Ductus venosus closes in 3-5 days
  • Ductus arteriosus closes in 7-10 days
  • Foramen ovale closes in 2-3 months

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 443

questions.text: A forensic expert is lecturing on the methods used to estimate the survival time of a newborn fetus in medicolegal investigations. Understanding these indicators is crucial for determining the time frame of survival post-delivery. Which of the following is not used to determine the survival time of a newborn fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Changes in middle ear

 

Option D:

 

Changes in the middle ear are not typically used to determine the survival time of a newborn fetus. This is just a sign of Live birth. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Caput succedaneum - This is an area of soft swelling that forms in the scalp over the presenting part of the head in vertex presentations. This can indicate trauma during delivery and may suggest survival time. This gradually diminishes within 2 to 4 days after birth

 

Option B. Changes in the umbilical cord: Umbilical cord blood clots at cut end 2 hrs after birth, inflammatory ring form at base in 36 to 48 hrs, mummifies on 2nd or 3rd day.

 

Option C. Changes in fetal circulation after birth can indicate the length of time the newborn survived. Umbilical vein and ductus venosus closed by 3rd day, ductus arteriosus by 10th day, foramen ovale by 2nd or 3rd month.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The changes in the middle ear are not reliable for determining a newborn's survival time post-birth. Indicators like caput succedaneum, changes in the umbilical cord, and alterations in fetal circulation are more informative for estimating the duration of life after birth in forensic examinations.

questions.text: During a forensic investigation involving the death of a newborn, a forensic Expert is examining the body to determine the age of the infant at the time of death. One of the key indicators in such cases is the stage of healing of the umbilical stump, known as cicatrisation. How many days after birth is cicatrisation of the umbilicus typically seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 12 days

 

Explanation:

 

Changes in Umblical Cord - The blood clots in the cut end 2 hours after birth, and the vessels begin to be closed in about 24 hours. The cord attached to the child shrinks and dries in 12 to 24 hours, but this appearance is also seen in the body of a stillborn infant , and an inflammatory ring forms at its base in 36 to 48 hours. It mummifies on second or third day. Mummification of the cord also occurs after death if exposed to air but does not occur if the child is submerged in water immediately after birth. The cord falls off on the fifth or sixth day and leaves an ulcer, which heals and forms a scar (Cicatrisation) in 10 to 12 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cicatrisation of the umbilicus, where the umbilical stump fully heals and falls off, is typically seen around 10-12 days after birth. This is a key milestone in the postnatal development of a newborn.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 443

questions.text: A forensic resident is examining a case of precipitate labor, where the labor and delivery occur very rapidly. In such cases, the umbilical cord can rupture due to the rapid birth process. Where is the umbilical cord usually ruptured in cases of precipitate labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal end

 

Explanation:

 

During precipitate labor, the umbilical cord is usually ruptured at the fetal end. The rapid and forceful nature of such deliveries can lead to a tear closer to the fetus.

 

PRECIPITATE LABOUR: Labor terminating in a very short time, occurs suddenly and rapidly, all the three stages of labor are merged into one. The foetus is normal or premature. It is possible in multipara with large roomy pelvis, but is extremely rare in Primipara. The child may die from (1) suffocation by falling into a lavatory pan, (2) head injury and fracture of the skull with subdural hemorrhage often bilateral, by a fall on a hard floor. if the woman was standing, and (3) hemorrhage from the torn end of the cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the typical location of umbilical cord rupture in cases of precipitate labor is fetal end

 

Head injury due to precipitate labor and blunt force

questions.text: A forensic expert is discussing Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) with medical students. SIDS is the unexplained death of a seemingly healthy infant. Among various theories, which is the most accepted explanation for SIDS?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sleep apnea

 

Option A:

 

The most accepted theory for SIDS involves sleep apnea, where the infant stops breathing during sleep. This interruption in breathing can lead to sudden and unexpected death in otherwise healthy infants.

 

SIDS (cot/crib death) - Sudden and unexpected death of seemingly healthy infant whose death remains unexplained even after complete autopsy. It is an autopsy diagnosis, and not a clinical diagnosis. Most of the death observed in age group between 2 weeks to 2 years. Mid infancy is the most vulnerable age (peak 2–4 months).

 

No definite cause is known. Prolonged sleep apnea is presently accepted as the most acceptable of the suggested causes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Milk allergy is not commonly linked to SIDS.

 

Option C. Critical diaphragm failure

 

Option D. Respiratory infection are potential factors but not as widely accepted as the primary explanation for SIDS.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the most accepted theory behind Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), focusing on sleep apnea as a key factor in these unexplained infant deaths.

questions.text: During a PG seminar, the topic of discussion is the common misconceptions and facts about cot death, also known as Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS). The participants are tasked with identifying false statements regarding SIDS. Which of the following statements about cot death is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Slightly female predominance

 

Option D:

 

The statement about SIDS having a slightly female predominance is false. SIDS is more commonly reported in male infants than in female infants. The other statements are generally consistent with the known characteristics and risk factors of SIDS.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased incidence if mother is alcoholic: This statement is true. There is evidence suggesting that maternal alcohol consumption can increase the risk of SIDS. Alcohol use during pregnancy can affect fetal development and may lead to conditions that predispose an infant to SIDS.

 

Option B. Most common finding is petechial hemorrhage on visceral surface of heart, lungs, thymus: This is also a true statement. In cases of SIDS, one of the most common autopsy findings is petechial hemorrhages, particularly on the visceral surfaces of the heart, lungs, and thymus. These tiny, pinpoint hemorrhages can be indicative of SIDS but are not exclusive to it.

 

Option C. It is a cause of negative autopsy: This statement is accurate. SIDS is often diagnosed when an autopsy does not reveal an adequate explanation for an infant's death. The term 'negative autopsy' is used because, despite thorough examination, no definitive cause of death can be identified. SIDS is essentially a diagnosis of exclusion, made after ruling out other potential causes of death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correcting misconceptions about Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, particularly regarding its gender distribution. Male infants have a proportionately higher death rate (M:F ratio 3:2).

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 447

questions.text: In a forensic investigation of an alleged infanticide, you have to examines the body of an infant found in a secluded area. To assist in the legal proceedings, the Medical Officer must determine if the infant was born alive. Certain physical signs can help in this assessment. Which of the following is not a typical sign of live birth in such forensic examinations?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Diaphragm is at the level of 4th rib

 

Option D:

 

The position of the diaphragm at the level of the 4th rib is not a sign specific to live birth. This can be a normal finding in both live-born and stillborn infants.

 

Signs of Live Birth

 

  • In India, live birth means the fetus was alive after complete birth or when at least one part of its body comes out of mother’s womb.
  • Any sign of life after complete birth of child is accepted as proof of live birth. Like - Baby’s cry (even if the head is inside the vagina—vagitus vaginalis, or inside the uterus—vagitus uterinus.), Muscle twitching/movements of limbs, Sneezing and yawning.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A dome-shaped chest can be observed as a result of the lungs expanding after taking the first breath.

 

Option B. The presence of air in the middle ear is indicative of respiration after birth.

 

Option C. Lungs that are elastic and spongy suggest that they have been inflated with air, a sign of live birth.

Postmortem findings - External and Internal findings

questions.text: In a medicolegal seminar focusing on child abuse, the topic of discussion is Battered Baby Syndrome, a severe form of child abuse resulting in serious injuries or death. The attendees, consisting of forensic experts and medical professionals, are asked about the most common cause of death in such cases, which is crucial for understanding the severity and nature of these injuries in forensic investigations.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Head injury

 

Option B:

 

In Battered Baby Syndrome, the most common cause of death is head injury. The impact of repeated or severe trauma to the head can lead to fatal brain injuries, which are often the primary cause of mortality in these cases. Second most common cause is the Rupture of abdominal organs

 

Caffey syndrome: It is also known as 'Battered baby syndrome' or 'Child abuse syndrome'. A Battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian. In addition to physical injury, there may be non-accidental deprivation of nutrition, care and affection. This is a rare pediatric disease characterized by inflammation and abnormal growth of bones

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Abdominal injuries: While abdominal injuries are a serious concern in cases of child abuse, they are the second most common cause of death in Battered Baby Syndrome. These injuries can include damage to internal organs like the liver, spleen, or intestines and can lead to significant health complications. However, they typically rank below head injuries in terms of fatality.

 

Option C. Chest injuries: Chest injuries in Battered Baby Syndrome can include rib fractures or lung contusions and can be severe. However, they are less likely to be immediately fatal compared to head injuries. The elasticity of the chest wall in infants often leads to less frequent or severe chest injuries compared to adults.

 

Option D. Septicemia: Septicemia, or blood infection, can occur in cases of severe neglect or abuse, potentially leading to death. However, it is not the most common cause of death in Battered Baby Syndrome. Septicemia might follow untreated wounds or prolonged health complications resulting from abuse, but it is not as direct or immediate a cause of death as a head injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding that head injuries are the most common and often the most severe injuries leading to death in cases of Battered Baby Syndrome.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 445

questions.text: During a forensic medicine lecture, the professor discusses the characteristic features of various injuries. One topic is the "six penny bruises", a term often encountered in child abuse cases. Which condition are six penny bruises most characteristic of?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Battered baby syndrome

 

Option A:

 

Six penny bruises are characteristic of Battered Baby Syndrome. These bruises are typically round and resemble the size of a small coin, such as a six penny piece. They often suggest a pattern of repeated physical abuse and are commonly seen in children who are victims of such maltreatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Crib Death: Also known as Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS), refers to the sudden, unexplained death of a healthy baby, usually during sleep. This condition is not associated with external injuries or bruising.

 

Option C. Road Traffic Accident: In road traffic accidents, the pattern of injuries and bruises varies greatly depending on the nature of the accident. While bruises are common in such incidents. Injuries in these cases are typically more random and dispersed and may include a range of abrasions, lacerations, and fractures.

 

Option D. Fall from Height: Falls from height can result in a variety of injuries, including fractures, internal injuries, and bruises. The injuries from falls are generally more related to the height and nature of the fall, and bruises, if present, tend to be larger and more irregular in shape.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing six penny bruises as a characteristic feature of Battered Baby Syndrome, indicative of repeated physical abuse in children.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 445

choices.text: Bucket handle fracture

questions.text: In a forensic practical session, students are discussing the radiological features of Caffey's Syndrome, a condition associated with non-accidental injuries in children. They are tasked with identifying which of the listed features is not associated with Caffey's Syndrome. Which of the following is not a radiological feature of Caffey's Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bumper's fracture

 

Option D:

 

Bumper's fracture, which is typically associated with vehicular accidents where the bumper hits the legs (Lateral tibial plateau fracture due to hit by bumper of a car to outer side of knee.), is not a radiological feature of Caffey's Syndrome.

 

Radiological features of Caffey's Syndrome

 

  1. Skull fracture in occipitoparietal area, involves multiple bones and suture. The skull fracture that radiates out in different direction is called Egg Shell Fracture.
  2. Multiple ribs fracture at posterior angle of ribs appeared as "a string of beads" on X-ray in the paravertebral gutter after callus formation. This is called Nobbing fractures.
  3. Metaphyseal fracture (also called bucket handle fracture or corner fracture): pathognomonic radiological finding.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bucket handle fracture: This is a metaphyseal lesion associated with non-accidental trauma seen in child abuse cases, not Caffey's Syndrome.

 

Option B. Corner fracture: Also known as a metaphyseal chip fracture, it is another indicator of non-accidental trauma.

 

Option C. String of beads: This refers to the appearance of multiple, rounded, well-defined densities along the ribs and is associated with Caffey's Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bumper's fracture, typical in vehicular accidents impacting the legs, is not a feature of Caffey's Syndrome, which instead presents radiologically with occipitoparietal skull fractures, multiple rib fractures resembling a string of beads, and metaphyseal fractures known as bucket handle or corner fractures.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 44

choices.text: Abrasion on the knees
Swelling in the occiput

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with multiple injuries. The child has an abrasion on the knees, swelling in the occiput, bleeding from the nose, and a subdural hematoma diagnosed through imaging. The parents claim these injuries were due to a fall while playing. Which of the following injuries is least likely to be a result of accidental trauma in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subdural hematoma

 

Option A:

 

Subdural hematoma in a child, especially in the absence of a reported significant head trauma, is highly suggestive of non-accidental injury (child abuse). It is less likely to be seen in typical accidental injuries compared to the other options.

 

Some important Pointers of Subdural Hematoma

 

  • It is essentially a venous or capillary bleeding, and not an arterial bleeding.
  • It is commonly seen over the upper lateral surface of cerebral hemispheres and most commonly supratentorial (frontotemporal region).
  • Cause - It is usually traumatic, following an assault or fall (70–75%), accidents account for another 20–25% of cases, but it can be due to secondary causes including alcoholism and anticoagulant therapy.
  • One of the most common head injuries ending fatally. SDH is caused due to acceleration -deceleration injury in which there is significant primary damage to brain parenchyma.
  • Caffey (1974) described the effects of shaking a child as a major cause of subdural haematoma and intraocular bleeding in battered babies, the so-called "infantile whiplash syndrome".
  • Types -
    • Acute - Signs are evident within 3 days of injury. It occurs due to rupture of large bridging veins or the cortical artery or due to cerebral laceration. It is mostly unilateral.
    • Sub-acute - Signs are evident between 4–21 days. It is due to rupture of smaller bridging veins.
    • Chronic or Pachymeningitis hemorrhagica interna chronica. Signs and symptoms appear > 3 weeks after trauma. It is most common in infants (< 6 months) and in the elderly (> 60 years). A history of head trauma may be elicited.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Abrasion on the knees: Common in children due to falls while playing.

 

Option C. Swelling in the occiput: Could occur due to accidental falls.

 

Option D. Bleeding from the nose: Not uncommon in children and can result from minor trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury patterns suggestive of non-accidental trauma in children - Subdural hematoma is a red flag for child abuse, especially in the absence of a history of significant accidental trauma.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 445

choices.text: Long bone fracture

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department with neurological symptoms. The parents report a history of violent shaking. No external injuries are visible. What is the most characteristic injury associated with the history of violent shaking in this infant?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subdural hematoma

 

Option C:

 

Subdural hematoma is a characteristic finding in shaken baby syndrome, resulting from the violent shaking causing the brain to move within the skull, leading to tearing of blood vessels.

 

Shaken baby syndrome: Infants are susceptible to subdural/subarachnoid hematoma and retinal hemorrhages due to vigorous shaking of the baby as a method of punishment.

 

  • Predisposing factors: Infant’s relatively large head, weak neck muscles and delicate subarachnoid bridging vessels.
  • Signs and symptoms: Seizures, irritability, meningismus and focal or general neurologic deficit.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmation by CT/MRI scan, bloody spinal or subdural fluid and normal skull X-rays.

 

 

Note - Caffey (1974) described the effects of shaking a child as a major cause of subdural haematoma and intraocular bleeding in battered babies, the so-called "infantile whiplash syndrome".

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Long bone fracture: More indicative of direct trauma.

 

Option B. Ruptured spleen: Uncommon in shaken baby syndrome.

 

Option D. Skull bone fracture: Typically results from impact injury, not shaking.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the characteristic injuries of shaken baby syndrome, with subdural hematoma being a key finding indicative of this form of child abuse.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 445

questions.text: As a pediatrician, you are collaborating with police in an ongoing investigation involving a 5-year-old child with numerous unexplained hospital admissions. Each admission was prompted by acute medical symptoms reported by the primary caregiver. However, extensive diagnostic testing has consistently failed to identify a definitive cause. Notably, the child's symptoms resolve rapidly when in hospital care, away from the caregiver. Considering the suspicious pattern and the involvement of law enforcement, what is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Factitious disorder

 

Option A:

 

Munchausen syndrome by proxy, now known as factitious disorder imposed on another, involves a caregiver fabricating or inducing illness in a child for attention or sympathy.

 

Munchausen syndrome by proxy (MSBP) or Factitious disorder

 

  • MSBP is a form of abuse in which a parent or guardian fabricates or produces symptoms of an illness in a child in order to gain sympathy or attention for themselves.
  • The parents frequently have abnormal or borderline personality disorder and may derive some non-economic benefit at the expense of the victim.
  • Diagnosis may require a high level of suspicion and may be met with considerable resistance from family.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Malingering: Involves feigning illness for external benefits, not applicable here.

 

Option C. Hysteria: An outdated term, not relevant to this scenario.

 

Option D. Conversion disorder: Involves neurological symptoms without a medical cause, not induced by someone else.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristics of Munchausen syndrome by proxy, where a caregiver causes or fabricates symptoms in a child, classified as a factitious disorder imposed on another.

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 446-447

questions.text: A forensic expert is performing an autopsy on a neonate to determine if the baby was born alive. The hydrostatic (lung floatation) test is conducted, but the expert considers conditions that might lead to a false negative result. Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause a false negative result in the hydrostatic test for a live-born neonate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atelectasis

 

Option A:

 

Atelectasis, or incomplete expansion of the lungs, can lead to a false negative result in the hydrostatic test. This test is based on the principle that the lungs of a live-born infant will float in water due to air inhalation. In atelectasis, the lungs may not be adequately aerated, causing them to sink, falsely suggesting that the infant was not born alive.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Meconium aspiration: While this can complicate the interpretation, it does not inherently cause false negatives as the lungs would still be aerated.

 

Option C. Emphysema: Typically causes the lungs to float, not sink.

 

Option D. Congenital heart disease: While it might affect lung development, it does not directly lead to false negatives in the hydrostatic test as the lungs can still be aerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the limitations of the hydrostatic test in determining live birth. Atelectasis can cause a false negative result, as the lungs of the neonate may not be sufficiently aerated to float, even if the child was born alive. This highlights the need for comprehensive autopsy findings and consideration of all possible factors that can influence such tests.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 440

Understand the importance of the ossification center in the talus as a marker for fetal viability.

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is explaining different methods used to estimate the age of fetuses and young children in forensic cases. What is the primary application of the Rule of Hasse?
questions.solution:
Ans A) Age of fetus

 

Option A:

 

Rule of Hasse (1895) 

 

It is a rough method of calculating the age of fetus. The length of fetus is measured from crown to heel in centimeters. During first 5 months of pregnancy—square root of length gives approximate age of fetus in months.

 

Haase's Modification of Morisson's Law - During the last 5 months—length in centimeters divided by 5 gives age in months.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Height of an adult: Not related to the Rule of Hasse.

 

Option C. Race of a person: The rule does not provide information on race.

 

Option D. Identification: While bone measurements can be part of identification processes, the Rule of Hasse specifically estimates fetal age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the use of the Rule of Hasse in forensic anthropology for estimating the age of a fetus based on crown to heel measurements.

 

Measurement of Age of fetus (during autopsy)

 

Osseous methods - ossification centers (20 weeks - calcaneum appears; 28 weeks - talus appear; 36 weeks - lower end of femur (36–37 weeks), cuboid and capitate appear; 38-40 weeks - upper end of tibia appears)

 

Non-osseous method - By weighing the infant and measuring the height (crown-heel length), various other measurements (crown–rump length, head circumference, chest circumference) and the foot length, estimating lung maturity (Progressive development of surfactant-producing alveolar Type-II cells)

questions.text: A forensic expert receives a conceptus material brought in by the police for examination. The conceptus measures 4 cm in length and weighs 10 grams. The expert is tasked with estimating its gestational age. Based on the given measurements, what is the most probable age of the conceptus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 8 weeks

 

Option D:

 

A conceptus measuring 4 cm in length and weighing 10 grams is most likely around 6 weeks of gestation. At this stage, the embryo has undergone significant development, including the formation of basic structures and organ systems.

 

Hasse's Rule:

For the first 5 months of gestation:

Age in months = (CHL in cm)

For after 5 months of gestation:

Age in months = (CHL in cm) 5

Applying Hasses Rule to this Case:

  • Given CHL = 4 cm
  • Since 4 cm < 25 cm, we use the first formula:

Age in months=4=2 months

Age in months=4 = 2 months 8 weeks

 

End of second month: Length four cm; weight ten gm. The hands and feet are webbed. The placenta begins to form. The anus is seen as a dark spot. First ossification center in a foetus appears in clavicle (4 to 5 weeks), followed by maxilla (6 weeks). Ossification centers are present in the upper segments of sacrum and mandible.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: 2 weeks - Cannot be determined. 

 

Option B: 4 weeks & Option C. 5 weeks - (End of first month) - Length 1 cm; weight 2.5 gm. The eyes are seen as two dark spots, and the mouth as a cleft.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 83-84

choices.text: Anatomic abnormality of the uterus

questions.text: During a forensic investigation into a suspected case of criminal poisoning, a pregnant woman in her first trimester suffered a spontaneous abortion. The forensic team is exploring various causes that could have led to this unfortunate event. As part of the medical evaluation to assist in the investigation, the forensic examiner is considering the most likely medical cause of the spontaneous abortion. What is the most common cause of spontaneous abortion in the first trimester that should be investigated in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chromosomal defect

 

Option A:

 

Chromosomal defects are the most common cause of spontaneous abortions in the first trimester. These defects can lead to the development of an embryo that is not viable, resulting in a miscarriage.

 

Natural Abortion: Abortion may occur at any time due to natural causes. Abortion occurs in 10 to 15% of all pregnancies and is most common about the second or third month.

 

2 types - a. Natural b. Accidental

 

Genetic causes - Majority of early spontaneous (Natural) abortions are due to chromosomal abnormality.

 

  • Autosomal trisomy is the commonest cause (50%) and most common is trisomy 16 (30%).
  • Monosomy and chromosomal aberration (including deletion, duplication, translocation and inversion) constitutes 20% and 2–4% of all abortions respectively.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Endocrine disturbances: While important, they are less common than chromosomal defects.

 

Option C. Anatomic abnormality of the uterus: A significant cause but less frequent than chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Option D. Infections: Can lead to miscarriage but are not the most common cause in the first trimester.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromosomal defects are the leading cause of spontaneous abortion in the first trimester, highlighting the importance of genetic factors in early pregnancy loss.

 

Causes of spontaneous (Natural) abortions –

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 400

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a postmortem examination in a district hospital on a 45-year-old male who was found dead in his home office. The deceased had a history of depression but no known physical health issues. The postmortem reveals no signs of physical trauma, but a white crystalline substance is found in the stomach contents. Toxicological analysis identifies the substance as borax. In this suspected suicide case, which pharmacological effect of borax is most pertinent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Emmenagogues

 

Option D:

 

Borax is classified as an emmenagogue (Abortifacient drugs). Emmenagogues are substances that stimulate or increase menstrual flow. Borax has been historically used for its emmenagogic properties, although it is not commonly used in modern medical practice due to safety concerns.

 

Emmenagogues drugs - estrogen, savin, borax or sanguinarine

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gastrointestinal irritants: These causes irritation of uterus, e.g. purgatives, like castor or croton oil, julap, senna or MgSO4.

 

Option B. Genitourinary irritants: They produce reflex uterine contraction, e.g. cantharides, oil of turpentine or tansy or pennyroyal.

 

Option C. Ecbolics: Refers to substances that stimulate uterine contractions. Ex - Ergot preparations, synthetic estrogens, pituitary extract, strychnine or quinine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abortifacient drugs: Most of them have no effect on the uterus or fetus, unless given in toxic doses, and often sold to exploit distressed woman. Usually used in the 2nd month of pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 402

questions.text: In a case under investigation at a district hospital, a medical officer is required to estimate the gestational age of a fetus as part of a forensic examination. This is crucial in a legal case involving questions around the time of conception and fetal viability. The medical officer refers to ultrasound findings for accurate dating of the pregnancy. At the earliest, by which week of gestation can the gestational sac be seen using ultrasonography?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5th week

 

Option C:

 

During a forensic autopsy, the gestational sac can typically be visualized using ultrasonography at the earliest by the 5th week of gestation. This information is crucial in determining the age of the fetus for forensic purposes.

 

Transvaginal sonography (TVS) can detect cardiac activity by 5th week and transabdominal sonography by 6th week. A real-time scanner can detect cardiac activity by 8th week. Doppler ultrasound can pick up the fetal heart rate reliably by 10th week (average 8–10 weeks).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 3rd week - Not visible

 

Option B. 4th week: Gestational sac is visible after 4 completed week

 

Option D. 8th week: By this time, more advanced fetal structures, beyond just the gestational sac, are visible in forensic ultrasonography, like - Eyes and nose recognizable, hands and feet are webbed. Anus is seen as dark spot. Placenta is formed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gestational sac, the earliest sonographic evidence of pregnancy, can typically be visualized by the 5th week of gestation. This is an important milestone in early pregnancy and is crucial for confirming intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Ref:  Reddy 33/e. Pg 396

choices.text: Direct Coomb’s test

questions.text: During a postmortem examination of a pregnant woman at a district hospital, a medical officer is investigating a case involving suspected complications related to fetomaternal hemorrhage. To determine if there was a transfusion of fetal red blood cells (RBCs) into the mother's circulation, a specific diagnostic test is required. Which test is used to detect fetomaternal transfusion of fetal RBCs in the mother's circulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Betke-Kleihauer test

 

Option B:

 

In a postmortem examination of a pregnant woman, the Betke-Kleihauer test is used to detect fetomaternal transfusion of fetal red blood cells (RBCs) in the mother's circulation. This information can be crucial in understanding the circumstances surrounding the individual's death, especially in cases involving maternal-fetal health issues.

 

Betke-Kleihauer test: This is a staining technique in which fetal cells can be distinguished from adult red cells. A blood smear is prepared from the mother’s blood and exposed to an acid bath. This removes adult hemoglobin, but not fetal hemoglobin from the red blood cells. Subsequent staining makes fetal cells (containing fetal hemoglobin) appear rose-pink in color, while adult red blood cells are only seen as ‘ghosts.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Direct Coomb’s test: Detects antibodies on the surface of red blood cells, not specifically for fetomaternal transfusion.

 

Option C. Electrophoresis: Used for analyzing the mobility of charged particles, not specific to this scenario.

 

Option D. Indirect Coomb’s test: Detects antibodies in the mother's serum, often used in blood typing and antibody screening, but not specific to fetomaternal transfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Betke-Kleihauer test during postmortem examinations of pregnant women, helps in detecting fetomaternal transfusion of fetal red blood cells in the mother's circulation. This knowledge is crucial in forensic postmortem examinations of pregnant women, particularly in cases where fetomaternal hemorrhage is suspected, to establish the cause and circumstances of complications or death.

 

Ref: Review of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3/e. Pg 358

questions.text: In a rural district hospital, a medical officer was called to investigate a distressing case involving a newborn found abandoned near a local pond. The circumstances surrounding the newborn's discovery raised concerns about possible infanticide. To assist in the investigation, the medical officer decided to perform a series of tests as part of the autopsy to determine whether the newborn had been born alive and breathed before death. In which test weight of lungs is compared with body weight?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ploucquet's Test

 

 

Option B:

 

Ploucquet's Test is the test in which weight of lungs is compared with body weight. This test helps to demonstrate establishment of respiration. The ratio of the weight of the lungs and the whole body is reduced to half (1/35 of body weight) as compared to before respiration (1/70 of body weight).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Static test or Fodere's test: The test based on lung weight useful in the diagnosis of live birth is static test. The average weight of both lungs before respiration is 35 gm and after respiration is 70 gm. There is no comparison with the body weight.

 

Option C. Raygats test (Hydrostatic test, Breslaus 1st life test): Raygats test is based on specific gravity of lung. The specific gravity of a non-respired lung is 1040-1050 and of a respired lung is 940-950, so, after respiration lung floats on water (specific gravity of water is 1000). There is no comparison of lung weight to body weight.

 

Option D. Wredin's test: This test is based on the fact that before birth middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic tissue, which is replaced by air after respiration. So, the presence of air in middle ears denotes live birth. There is no role of weight of lungs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 439

questions.text: In a challenging case of suspected neonatal demise under ambiguous circumstances, a forensic expert was tasked with conducting an autopsy to ascertain the viability and respiratory status of the neonate at birth. The expert performed a hydrostatic test, a conventional method used in forensic medicine to evaluate if a newborn had initiated respiration. Which condition is most likely to be associated with a false-negative result in the hydrostatic test in a live-born fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atelectasis

 

 

Option A:

 

Atelectasis refers to the partial or complete collapse of the lung or a section (lobe) of the lung, which occurs when the tiny air sacs (alveoli) within the lung become deflated. In the context of a newborn, atelectasis can lead to a false-negative result in the hydrostatic test because even if the newborn has initiated respiration, the collapsed alveoli may prevent the lungs from floating in water. This condition might suggest that the neonate did not breathe, even though respiration was attempted or partially achieved. Atelectasis could be due to a variety of reasons, including delayed or inadequate expansion of the lungs at birth.

 

Hydrostatic test (Raygat's test, 1st life test): The specific gravity of a non-respired lung is 1040-1050 and of a respired lung is 940-950, so, after respiration lung floats on water (specific gravity of water is 1000).

 

Inference –

 

  • If they sink—unrespired lung.
  • If they float—remove them from water, cut into small pieces and then squeeze or compress firmly between sponges, and again put into water.
    • If they sink—unrespired lung.
    • If they float—respired lung.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Artificial Respiration: Artificial respiration typically introduces air into the lungs, which would likely cause the lungs to float, potentially leading to a false-positive rather than a false-negative result in the hydrostatic test.

 

Option C. Emphysema: Neonatal emphysema, characterized by overinflation of the lungs, would more likely cause the lungs to float, which does not correspond to a false-negative result.

 

Option D. Putrefaction: Putrefaction involves the production of gases within the body's tissues, including the lungs, after death. This process could lead to a false-positive result in the hydrostatic test, as the gas might cause the lungs to float, falsely indicating that the neonate had initiated respiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

False positive hydrostatic test may occur (i.e.non-respired lung may float) in decomposition and in attempted artificial respiration.

 

False negative hydrostatic test (i.e. respired lung may sink down) may occur in atelectasis, pulmonary oedema, bronchopneumonia, and congenital syphilis.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 439-440

choices.text: Rigor mortis at birth

questions.text:
In a rural district hospital, a medical officer was called to attend to a tragic case involving a dead born fetus. Upon examination, the medical officer observed certain postmortem changes in the fetus. One notable absence in the fetus was a specific postmortem phenomenon that is typically absent at birth in cases of dead-born.

 

Which postmortem phenomenon is most likely to be absent in a dead-born fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adipocere formation
 

Option B:

 

Adipocere formation: Adipocere, also known as "grave wax," is a postmortem change that occurs when body fat undergoes hydrolysis and saponification. It is unlikely to be observed in a dead-born fetus as it requires more time and specific environmental conditions to develop.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rigor mortis, the stiffening of muscles after death, is a postmortem phenomenon. It may be seen in dead-born fetus.

 

Option C. Maceration: Maceration is a process of aseptic autolysis. It occurs when a dead fetus remains in the uterus surrounded by liquor amnii but with exclusion of air. Skin slippage is the earliest sign.

 

Note - If the membranes are ruptured after death of fetus and air enters liquor amnii, fetus undergoes putrefaction instead of maceration. Body is greenish, foul smelling and bloated.

 

Option D. Mummification: It results when there is deficient blood supply, scanty liquor and no air enters uterus. Body is thin, shrivelled dark brown and emitting smell like rotten cheese.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Two cardinal signs to identify a dead born fetus are the presence of maceration along with lack of lung aeration (‘primary atelectasis’).

 

Differentiation between Stillborn and dead-born fetus

Infection of both vagina and uterus

questions.text: During a forensic autopsy at a regional medical college, the case of a pregnant woman and her unborn child's sudden death is examined. The circumstances of her death are unclear, prompting a thorough investigation that includes interviews with the attending birth personnel and medical staff. Amidst the investigation, the term "Vagitus Vaginalis" is brought up in relation to the unborn child, leading to discussions among the forensic team. What does the term "Vagitus Vaginalis" refer to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A cry of unborn baby from vagina

 

Option C:

 

"Vagitus Vaginalis" is a term used to describe the phenomenon in which an unborn baby emits a cry or sound while the baby is still in vagina. This unique occurrence can be heard during specific medical examinations involving pregnant individuals. It is important to note that "Vagitus Vaginalis" is unrelated to infections of the vagina or uterus.

 

 Signs of live birth:

 

  • Babys cryStrong evidence in favor of live birth and respiration having taken place. Fetus may inhale air and cry when the head is inside the vaginavagitus vaginalis, or inside the uterusvagitus uterinus.

  • Muscle twitching/movements of limbs.

  • Sneezing and yawning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagitus uterinus: Cry of an unborn child in Uterus

 

Vagitus vaginalis: Cry of an unborn child in Vagina

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 440

An infection of the uterus

Ans. D) A cry of an unborn baby from the Vagina

"Vagitus Vaginalis" is a term that defines the phenomenon where an unborn baby emits a cry or sound that appears to originate from the vagina rather than the uterus. It is a distinctive occurrence related to fetal activity and is not associated with infections of the vagina or uterus.

choices.text: Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS)
Congenital Heart Disease

questions.text: A forensic expert is reviewing the autopsy report of a 4-month-old infant who unexpectedly died during sleep. The infant was previously healthy with no history of respiratory or cardiac issues. The autopsy reveals no signs of trauma, infection, or congenital anomalies. The death occurred during sleep, in a safe sleeping environment. The expert is considering the most likely diagnosis. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS)

 

Option A:

 

Sudden Infant Death Syndrome [SIDS, Cot Death or Crib Death]

 

Definition: Sudden and unexpected death of seemingly healthy infant whose death remains unexplained even after complete autopsy. It is an autopsy diagnosis, not a clinical diagnosis.

 

Some important features - Incidence is 0.2–0.4% of all live births; commonly affected age is between 2 weeks to 2 years. Mid infancy is the most vulnerable age (peak 2–4 months). Male infants have a proportionately higher death rate (M: F ratio 3:2).

 

More common in low to middle-class families with poor housing and health awareness. Often found dead in early morning or after first morning feed. Predominantly in rainy and winter seasons in temperate zones, no clear pattern in tropical zones. Higher incidence in twins, associated with prematurity and low birth weight. Increased risk with prenatal or postnatal smoking and maternal drug abuse.

 

Causes - No definite cause is known.

 

  • Primary: Prolonged sleep apnea leading to hypoxia.
  • Contributing Factors: Respiratory infections, narrowed airways, local hypersensitivity, obstructed airways by bedclothes, prone sleeping position.
  • Miscellaneous: Various physiological and environmental factors.

 

Postmortem Findings - usually negative.

 

  • Trachea may contain milky vomit, sometimes blood-stained.
  • Agonal petechial hemorrhages on heart, lungs, and thymus.
  • Common pulmonary edema.
  • Milk or bloodstained froth at mouth or bedding.

 

Medico- legal Aspects:

 

  • Considered a natural death.
  • Importance in differentiating from infanticide and assessing parental involvement or negligence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Acute Bronchiolitis: This typically presents with signs of respiratory distress, which would have been noted prior to death.

 

Option C. Congenital Heart Disease: Significant congenital heart anomalies are generally identified through clinical symptoms or during autopsy.

 

Option D. Accidental Suffocation: This would likely show evidence of asphyxiation or an unsafe sleeping environment, which was not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS), or cot death or crib death is the sudden and unexpected death of seemingly healthy infant, whose death remains unexplained even after thorough case investigation, death scene examination, review of clinical history and complete autopsy.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 447
